Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 47030  
Project Preparatory Technical Assistance (PPTA) 
September 2013 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Preparing the Jiangxi 
Pingxiang Integrated Rural-Urban Infrastructure 
Development Project
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) for this technically complex water and 
other municipal infrastructure and services project is necessary to further define and optimize 
scope  and  project  impact,  assess  and  identify  most  suitable  sub-components,  provide 
innovative and international best practices input, and facilitate added value to the project. 
   
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The primary outputs of the TA will be four reports (inception, interim, draft final, and final 
report) and a knowledge product. Some of the main activities and outputs are (i) analysis on 
how the project will promote balanced rural and urban development and urban-rural integration, 
including  policy  dialogue  on  common  institutional  frameworks,  shared  administrative 
arrangements, and common water resources and water use management (i.e., water resources, 
river basin ecology and flood risk management, solid waste management, etc.); (ii) sector 
analysis of water supply and sanitation, solid waste management, river ecology integrated with 
flood risk and land use management, prepare a common water safety plan, and conduct a river 
basin ecological baseline assessment; (iii) technical design review of draft feasibility study 
reports and technical inputs, including the incorporation of lessons learned from previous Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) funded projects in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in related 
sectors,1 and study the project’s potential linkages to ADB-funded projects in Jiangxi and Hunan 
province, and ensure safeguards compliance suitable for ADB financing; (iv) economic and 
financial analysis, including least-cost analysis, cost effectiveness analysis and affordability 
analysis,  financial  reviews,  and  analysis  of  each  project  component,  as  well  as  detailed 
assessment of the financial management capacity and performance of the Pingxiang Municipal 
Government (PMG), the Pingxiang Urban Construction Investment and Development Company 
(PUCIDC), and the district/county level project implementation units, in accordance with ADB 
guidelines;  (v)  poverty  and  social  assessment  survey  and  analysis,  reports  on  community 
consultations for poverty and social analysis, and consultation and participation plan aligned 
with ADB requirements;2 (vi) resettlement plan, social development action plan, and gender 
action plan meeting effective gender mainstreaming categorization requirements and ethnic 
minority  assessment  to  confirm  category  C;3 (vii)  community  participation  plan  and  public 
awareness  campaign  program;  (viii)  environmental  impact  assessments  (EIAs)  review  and 
finalization following requirements specified in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009); (ix) 
environmental management  plan; (x) risk  assessment  and management  plan,  including  on 
public financial management, procurement, anticorruption, and technical capabilities; and (xi) 
institutional capacity development plan and public awareness campaigns plan. Detailed outputs 
of the TA consultants will include but will not be limited to: 
(i)  Sector and subsector analysis. The consultants will review national, provincial, and 
municipal  12th  Five-Year  Plans;  National  Spatial  Development  Plan;  Pingxiang 
Municipal Master Plan 2008–2020; and other relevant documents. Based on sector

due diligence, lessons learned from previous ADB-funded projects in the PRC and 
international best practices, the consultants will assess the project rationale and give 
recommendations for strengthening project design and implementation arrangements. 
(ii)  Technical design. The consultants will review and recommend improvements to the 
overall sector systems planning and the effective and efficient integration of water 
supply, wastewater treatment, solid waste management, and flood risk management 
and plan for their simultaneous and coordinated implementation. The consultants will 
review designs of all components to ensure they are properly scaled to meet demand, 
technically sound and compatible with local conditions, meet all relevant technical 
standards  and  safeguard  requirements,  and  are  suitable  for  ADB  financing.  The 
consultants will perform risk assessment for projects and associated projects, including 
existing dams that connect to water supply sub-components of the project. Based on 
the analysis and best national and international practices, the consultants will conduct 
cost-benefit analysis of various options, including the without project option, perform 
detailed feasibility studies of short-listed options, and recommend innovations and 
improvements to refine technical design of each project and sub-component. The 
consultants will closely monitor and include directions of the new urban development 
program that is due to be released in 2013. 
(iii)  Economic analysis. The consultants will conduct economic analysis of the project, 
including an assessment of the competing demands for water and water efficiency, 
contingent  valuation  survey  and  analysis,  least-cost  analysis,  cost  effectiveness 
analysis and affordability analysis, where applicable, to ensure that the economic 
analysis  meets  ADB  requirements. 4 Economic  rationale  will  be  developed  and 
economic justification will be evaluated for each component and the project as a whole. 
(iv)  Financial analysis. The consultants will undertake financial reviews and analysis of 
each project component, as well as detailed assessment of the financial performance 
of PMG and PUCIDC in accordance with ADB guidelines.5 This due diligence includes 
financial management assessment, including analysis of the internal and external audit 
systems of the PMG, PUCIDC, and district/county governments, as well as analysis of 
their financial strength and status. It will include analysis of the soundness of the 
financing  plan  and the  availability  and  sustainability  of  counterpart funding. It  will 
include  an  analysis  of  possible  cofinancing  sources,  including  private  sector 
engagement especially  for revenue  generating  components  such  as public-private 
partnerships for solid waste management facilities (e.g., waste-to-energy or sanitary 
landfill  projects)  based  on  lessons  learned  from  previous  ADB  waste-to-energy 
projects in the PRC. The project will be subjected to least-cost, cost-benefit and fiscal 
analyses,  and  financial  analyses  of  revenue-generating  components  such  as 
water/wastewater tariff, solid waste service fees, etc. (considering affordability).6   
(v)  Procurement plan and procurement documents. The consultants will undertake (a) 
a comprehensive procurement capacity assessment of PMG, PUCIDC, and the project

implementing units in accordance with ADB guidelines and templates,7 (b) prepare a 
draft procurement plan, including consolidation and aggregation in bid packaging of 
various civil works and equipment, (c) design draft model bidding documents, and (d) 
conduct training events in ADB’s procurement and consultant’s rules and procedures. 
(vi)  Poverty  and  social  assessment. The consultants will engage a qualified survey 
institute to conduct household survey and community consultations for poverty and 
social analysis in accordance with ADB requirements.8 The consultants will review 
current  poverty  reduction  policies  and  regulations,  assess  socioeconomic  profiles, 
identify potential impacts on the poor or disadvantaged, prepare a consultation and 
participation plan, conduct key informant and focus group discussions, analyze the 
survey  data,  and  prepare  a  poverty  and  social  assessment  which  will  make 
recommendations for design, implementation, and monitoring to strengthen the project 
development impacts. From the survey, the consultants will establish a baseline and 
quantify the expected number of rural and urban beneficiaries. Based on this analysis, 
the consultants will prepare a social development action plan, and summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy in accordance with ADB guidelines and templates.  
(vii)  Gender action plan. The consultants will prepare a gender action plan in accordance 
with ADB guidelines with the objective of ensuring that the project maximizes benefits 
for women and meets effective gender mainstreaming categorization requirements.9 
(viii)  Community  participation  plan  and  public  awareness  campaign  program. The 
consultants will prepare, through participatory approach, a comprehensive plan for 
community involvement in, and public awareness for, water supply and distribution, 
wastewater and waste management, and river rehabilitation and management, as well 
as general aspects of environmental protection, public health, and safety.  
(ix)  Environmental assessment. The consultants will review the EIAs prepared for each 
project component and ensure that all EIAs meet the requirements specified in ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement. Based on the review, the consultants will prepare a 
consolidated EIA, including an environmental management plan both in English and 
Chinese in ADB’s required format. The consultants will provide guidance to PMG, the 
local institutes, and the EIA preparation team on ADB’s environmental assessment 
requirements as laid out in the safeguards policy. 
(x)  Involuntary resettlement assessment. The consultants will review draft resettlement 
plans and assist PMG to engage a qualified survey institute to conduct surveys, and 
improve and finalize the resettlement plans in accordance with ADB requirements. 10 
(xi)  Ethnic minority (indigenous peoples) assessment. The consultants will conduct a 
thorough scoping of ethnic minority issues in the project area and confirm category C 
for  indigenous  peoples  safeguards  (or,  if  deemed  necessary,  prepare  an  ethnic 
minority development plan) in accordance with ADB requirements.11  
(xii)  Risk assessment and management plan. The consultants will assess the financial 
management  system,  accounting  rules  and  practices,  administrative  procedures, 
internal  control  and  audit  systems,  external  audit,  technical  capabilities,  and 
procurement  capacity  and  practices  of  PMG,  PUCIDC,  and  the  district/county

governments. Based on this assessment, the consultants will identify potential project-
related risks in four specific thematic issues namely: (a) public financial management, 
(b) procurement, (c) anti-corruption, and (d) technical capabilities, and prepare a draft 
governance risk assessment and management plan. Funds flow and disbursement 
arrangements will also be identified reflecting the governance assessment.  
(xiii)  Institutional strengthening and capacity development plan. The consultants will 
prepare a capacity development plan outlining trainings and institutional strengthening 
measures to enhance the capacity of PMG, PUCIDC, and other concerned agencies to 
meet needs of ADB loan-funded project implementation and ensure future managerial, 
technical, and financial sustainability of operations. The consultants will establish the 
terms of reference for PMG and PUCIDC in developing a project management office, 
and  conduct  training  workshops  on  ADB  guidelines  and  procedures  for  project 
processing and implementation. The consultants will provide input for a policy dialogue 
to facilitate effective and integrated management of water supply, wastewater, and 
solid waste management, i.e., through the creation of a municipal water bureau. 
(xiv)  Design and monitoring framework (DMF). The consultants, in consultation with all 
stakeholders will develop a DMF in accordance with the Guidelines for Preparing a 
DMF.12 The  consultants  will  collect  and  confirm  baseline  indicators  and  develop 
performance  indicators  for  impact,  outcome,  and  outputs  of  the  project,  including 
income, poverty, employment, health, gender, technical, social, and environmental 
data.  
(xv)  Project administration manual (PAM). The consultants will prepare a PAM which will 
(a) include all linked documents and attachments, including a project implementation 
plan,  project  readiness  filters,  etc.;  (b)  specify  participating  agencies’  roles  and 
responsibilities; (c) identify implementation arrangements, including detailed costs and 
financing  plan;  financial  management;  consulting  services  and  procurement; 
safeguards; performance monitoring, evaluation, reporting, and communications; and 
accountability mechanisms; and (d) include an S-curve quarterly projection of contract 
awards and disbursement for the duration of project implementation. The PAM will be 
prepared through a consultative process that engages stakeholders throughout. 
 (xvi) Knowledge product. The consultants will prepare guidance notes for environmentally 
sustainable  and  socially  inclusive,  balanced  rural  and  urban  development,  and 
coordinated river basin and resources management.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $840,000 equivalent, of which $600,000 equivalent will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources),

Trust  Fund  under  the  Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility  (WFPF)  administered  by  ADB, 
funding phase 1.13 The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, provision of office space, communication 
facilities, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  The consulting activities will be carried out in two phases. For phase 1, from October 
2013 to March 2014, individual consultants will be recruited for a total of 16 person-months. For 
phase 2, from November 2013 to September 2014, a consulting firm will be engaged for a total 
of  42  person-months  in  line  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2013,  as 
amended from time to time) using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality-
cost ratio of 90:10 due to project complexity and importance of strong integration of components 
for the overall sustainability of the project, using the simplified technical proposal procedure.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Phase 1 Consultants 
 
1.  Water resources management specialist/team leader (national, 3.0 person-months). 
The  expert  shall  be  professionally  qualified,  with  a  minimum  of  a  Master’s  degree  in 
environmental engineering, hydrology, or related field, and must have 15 years of relevant 
professional work experience in water resources management, watershed management, river 
hydrology and ecology, flood protection works, river landscaping, integrated climate change 
adaptation, and related areas. The expert will  
 
(i)  Review  national,  regional,  and  municipal  12th  Five-Year  Plans,  Pingxiang 
municipality  and  counties  master  plans,  population  growth  estimates,  capacity 
evaluations, and other relevant development and sector plans. 
(ii)  In  conjunction  with  the  hydrologists,  analyze  river  basin  hydraulic  system  and 
historic flood occurrence, and develop a sector study and plan to help determine 
flood occurrence and options for flood risk management, both physical and non-
physical. 
(iii)  Establish  baseline  and  performance  targets  for  impact,  outcome,  and  output 
indicators relating to river rehabilitation and flood risk works components.  
(iv)  Technical review of the feasibility study reports (FSRs) and designs, and critically 
review  national  standards  and  compare  with  international  standards  and  best 
practices. 
(v)  In  conjunction  with  other  team  members,  identify  social  and  environmental 
upstream  and  downstream  impacts  of  river  rehabilitation  and/or  flood  plain 
modification, including reduced or increased flood potential.  
(vi)  In conjunction with other team members, develop several alternative solutions, 
including  the  no-action  option,  and  analyze  and  evaluate  from  the  technical, 
environmental, economic, social, resettlement, institutional, and urban planning 
perspectives. 
(vii)  In  conjunction  with  the  landscape  ecological  design  and  land  use  specialist, 
recommend  innovative  features  in  urban  river  rehabilitation  works  and  flood 
protection to enhance environmental sustainability, climate change resilience, and 
cost effectiveness, which may include floodplain conservation programs, retention 
and detention wetlands, parks and ponds, and local floodplain ordinances that 
regulate activities and restricts/prohibits building in floodplains.  
(viii)  Work with the landscape ecological design and land use specialist in developing an 
integrated  river  rehabilitation  design  with  flood  risk  management  that  uses 
principles  of  eco-engineering,  retention  of  natural  flood-plains  and  wetlands, 
natural buffer zones, constructed nature-like flood works with wetlands and rocks, 
and maximize green areas as opposed to straight, engineered concrete structures 
and embankments. 
(ix)  Develop a water safety plan in conjunction with other team members following 
Asian Development Bank (ADB)/World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines. 
(x)  Provide  inputs  on  cost  estimates,  procurement  plan,  appropriate  contract 
packaging,  implementation  schedule,  bid  documents,  and  terms  of  references 
(TORs) for project implementation consultants. 
(xi)  Identify  opportunities  for  institutional  strengthening,  capacity  development,  and 
non-engineering interventions, such as flood warning systems, disaster response 
plans, etc. and propose a capacity development program.

8  Attachment 
 
2.  Urban and regional planner/deputy team leader (international, 2.0 person-months). 
The expert shall be professionally qualified, with a minimum of a Master’s degree in urban and 
regional  planning  or  related  field,  and  must  have  15  years  of  relevant  professional  work 
experience in urban and regional strategic and land use planning, urban and rural economic 
development planning, rural-urban transition planning, and infrastructure planning. The expert 
will 
 
(i)  Review  national,  regional,  and  municipal  12th  Five-Year  Plans;  Pingxiang 
municipality and counties master plans; population growth estimates; infrastructure 
capacity evaluations; and other relevant development and sector plans. 
(ii)  Provide comments and recommendations on the projected growth in the plans 
relative  to  Pingxiang’s  development  potentials  and  constraints,  specific  to  its 
location in the region. 
(iii)  Assess proposed sector plans and infrastructure needs for no growth, slow growth, 
and even declining population scenarios. 
(iv)  Analyze  the  current  urban  and  rural  structure  and  land  use  patterns,  and  its 
economic and social geography. 
(v)  Assess  the  potentials  for  rural-urban  development  integration  specific  to  the 
municipality  and  the  counties,  considering  the  development  of  the  agri- 
manufacturing and service industries. 
(vi)  Assist  in  defining  the  project’s  strategy  and  understanding  of  “rural-urban 
integration”. 
(vii)  Provide international and national best practices and case studies that illustrate 
economically diverse, sustainable rural-peri-urban and urban regions with effective 
infrastructure,  reduced  rural-urban  income  gap,  and  ecological  infrastructure 
services. 
(viii)  Develop concepts for integrated development plans for land use, transportation, 
and environmental infrastructure optimizing benefits and synergies. 
(ix)  Develop  strategies  and  concepts  for  physical  and  operational  measures  for 
maximizing direct and indirect benefits of the project for rural and urban areas and 
people in Pingxiang. 
(x)  Recommend catalyzing measures creating more benefits from the project. 
 
3.  Hydrologists  and  flood  risk  management  specialists  (international,  2.0  person-
months; national, 3.0 person-months). The experts shall be professionally qualified, with a 
minimum of a graduate degree in civil engineering or related field, and must have 12/8 years 
(international/national)  of  relevant  professional  work  experience  in  hydrology,  hydraulic 
modeling, flood risk mapping, geographic information system operation, flood risk management, 
and other relevant areas of expertise. The experts will  
 
(i)  Analyze watersheds and river basins hydraulic systems, and obtain existing digital 
and analog data and models, if any. 
(ii)  Develop a digital 3D model and a hydraulic model for the relevant project rivers 
incorporating all relevant hydraulic, topographic, geologic, meteorological, etc. data. 
(iii)  Review  and  include  in  the  model  existing  and  planned  flood  protection 
infrastructure, and assess the impact on storm-water management and flooding in 
the urban and rural areas upstream and downstream of the existing and planned 
interventions. 
(iv)  Develop flood risk maps for the scenario without planned flood protection works 
interventions  and  for  the  scenario  with  the  currently  planned  flood  protection

Attachment  9 
 
 
interventions,  including a  larger  area  upstream  and  downstream  analyzing  the 
effects on the territory, people, and environment of reduced or increased flood risk. 
(v)  In conjunction with the other specialists, develop alternative urban and rural flood 
risk management options for the larger river basin, using and analyzing various 
options in the model and generating a series of flood risk maps for the options. 
(vi)  Support the development of a water safety plan following ADB/WHO guidelines. 
(vii)  Consider climate change effects, as well as historic flood occurrence, to analyze 
the future flood risk.  
(viii)  Assess  institutional  capacity  development  needs  with  respect  to  hydro-system 
analysis and hydraulic modeling of the executing agency, implementing agency, 
and project implementation units (PIUs) and develop capacity development plans. 
(ix)  Perform capacity development trainings for leaders to comprehend the principles of 
modeling and the technology used and provide training to technical staff of the 
project institutions on model generation, and model application and mapping. 
 
4.  Ecologist and biodiversity specialist (national, 2.0 person-months). The expert shall 
be scientifically qualified, with a minimum of a Master’s degree in biology, ecology, or related 
field, and must have a minimum of 12 years of relevant work experience in habitat analysis; 
biodiversity assessment; river, wetland, and aquatic ecology; and similar relevant areas. The 
expert will 
 
(i)  Analyze and evaluate the biodiversity and the ecological value and sensitivities of 
the river basin and river habitat. 
(ii)  Create an inventory of past and current flora (and fauna) in the ecosystem. 
(iii)  Perform an ecological categorization and classification of the aquatic ecosystem
